ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
0. History of Astronomy
1. The life of a normal star(main sequence stars, pre and post m-s stars, giants, red giants, AGB, white dwarf, neutron stars, blackholes, supernova......) and their characteristics, 
2. unique type of stars(like pulsars and variable stars)
3. Galaxy type, characteristics
4. Cosmology(Hubble Law)
5. useful calculations(so called 'envelope-back calculation') in Astronomy
6. how modern astronomy research is carried out (different wavelength to observe different objects, famous ground based telescope and space telescope)
so many beauuuuuutiful photos of nebula and galaxy!!

I am pursuing an independent research program at UChicago to classify Dark Matter candidates using the Fourth Fermi-LAT Catalog and this esteemed course has been of great interest to me. I was always fascinated by Astronomy and will soon be an AeroAstro and Astrophysics prospective student at Stanford. But I wanted to have a proper, structured introduction to the field, which ASTR120 provided me.
General understanding of the universe and our solar system

Wow it's actually like an introduction to nearly EVERYTHING about the universe. 
First, I via this course regained my interest in Science despite my complete and sad isolation from it (I am currently a language major.) And in this course, I started again to calculate figures and think in a more logical way, which was a very delighting experience.
Second, I found something special in this course. I took this course in Shanghai, China at midnight those weeks, and the nights and darkness really encouraged me to do some philosophical thinking, i.e. about the universe, the meaning of our life, and our destinies. 
In addition, I think it is really good to know the abcs about astronomy, since it is somehow quite embarrassing that as an earth resident, I have never been able to figure out why the sky looks blue. This course via providing me with some basic understanding of the universe and us, helps enrich my learning experience and also life experience: it made feel more COMPLETE.
The basic and fundamental principles of astronomy
While I was taking this course, I learned about Physics. Ive never taken Physics during my years at high school, but Ive learned a lot after this course.
Skills and history of astronomy
I learned about different types of celestial bodies. and the methods to measure the distances between earth and stars. also, I learned that earth is a miracle in the universe.
I gained better understanding of the workings of celestial bodies.
I gained a general sight about the subject of astronomy and gained more knowledge about our galaxies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
uhh, I think it's very good..
I am a foreign student, and I think what Prof.Zinn taught in the class is pretty clearly and easy to understand and I can catch up with the lessons without lots of after-class time.
But I think maybe the slides can be better...?I mean the font size. 
And if some scanning of hand-writings are replaced by the typing-in, the slides will be more friendly...

I have nothing to complain about. I just wish it had been longer :( and possibly include more Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and More Math! I would love to take a more physics-maths intensive course on the same subjects of Stars and Galaxies.

This course is interesting, but having class everyday was a bit overwhelming. Maybe its because I was taking 2 summer classes, but I feel as though the abundance of time made it harder for me to gauge what exactly to study/what we would be tested on.

I somehow think the the last chapters are a little over-difficult while the first several ones are much too easy, which failed to make this course in terms of the difficulty level very "gradual" in a sense. However, I still want to announce that it is my favourite course of the year! The instructor and the TAs are really nice, knowlegeable, and extremely responsible at their work. And also, the textbook and the lectures worked well with each other: when sometimes I had trouble understanding the lectures, I coud always turn to the texbook, and vice versa.
And I think the best thing was that I could always find my helpers, the Prof and the TAs when I was in need. As a language major, I found it hard to fully understand the contents of the course; throughout the course, to help me with that, the TAs and our Prof displayed great patience and their extraordinaly knowledge, via writing and replying to the emails, and offering the students adequate office hours, discussion sessions, and many other channels through which the students could explore the unclear concepts and ideas. I was moved and grateful, since due to my location, it was not very convenient for the TAs to receive my messages every time, but they truly wanted to help and we finally solve the location problem. Everyone was just so nice in this course!
My strength was that I love to do Math, so I was opened to learning Calculus. My weaknesses were that I had no idea about Physics or Calculus, so I had some struggle in the beginning.
This course was close to perfect
the contents of the course are clearly organized.
Online and over the summer, I had very little interaction with the faculty and felt little connection with the material.
I think this course introduces many knowledge about astronomy which is very good, but need more interactions and activities.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Yes.
The course is a very comprehensive one, covering almost all aspects of modern astronomy. 
If the course is offline, and astronomical observation activities can be held on campus, it will be better.(Although it becomes online due to the COVID19)

Yessssss! The TAs, the professor, the learning environment, and the entire process of simplifying such high-level Astronomical Phenomena at a learning-by-doing level for enthusiasts and prospective majors such as myself makes me want to recommend the course to as many friends as I can :)
If a student is interested in astronomy, I would say take it. If not so much, maybe pass because this class is a lot of work and is a big time commitment.

Yes, defintely. 
I was so surprised at our Prof's humorous and warm personality, and ergo I think everyone should have the chance to meet with him in person, learning the best astronomy knowledge from him. And owing to him, I agree that astronomy is something very fascinating and should be learned at least at the abc level, since it is so interesting and very relative to our real life.
Via learning astronomy, I found out that compared with the universe, I am negligibly small. Due to that, I abandoned some unnecessary worries in my recent life and managed to have a fresh start. I think this "philosophical thinking" will help every student participating in this course.
If you need a science credit it is a good class to take
I would recommend this course to anyone who has taken either Calculus or Physics. I would not recommend this course to anyone who has not, unless they are up for a challenge!
Yes. Professor Zinn is an excellent professor who is also very nice and friendly.
yes. this course broaden my horizons, tell me about worlds outsides the earth
No - I thought that it was not very interesting and the material was not covered well.
Yes, this course is very suitable for unprofessional people who are interested in astronomy
DO NOT take this course if you are thinking about learning about our galaxy and planet. Course was essentially a math class with the amount of homework and psets.
